title: 114_s3445
content: The Act is titled the "Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Improvement Act of 2016." It includes provisions for enforcing employment and reemployment rights of uniformed services members with state or private employers. The Act "Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Improvement Act of 2016" includes provisions for enforcing rights of uniformed services members with employers. It allows the Attorney General to initiate actions on behalf of individuals entitled to rights or benefits sought, with the option for the individual to intervene and obtain relief. The Attorney General must notify the servicemember of their decision within 60 days of receiving a referral. The Attorney General must inform the individual of their decision within 60 days of receiving a referral. If a decision has been made regarding relief, the person will be notified. If a decision has not been made, the person will be informed of when a decision is expected to be made. If a decision timeline is provided, the Attorney General must notify the individual of the decision within 30 days of that date. (c) Pattern or Practice Cases.--The Attorney General may take action if there is reasonable cause to believe a State or private employer is resisting rights secured by this chapter. Private persons can be notified if the Attorney General does not intend to bring a civil action. A conforming amendment is made to subsection (h)(2) of the section. The Attorney General can take action in pattern or practice cases if there is resistance to rights secured by this chapter. Private persons may be notified if the Attorney General does not plan to bring a civil action. Subsection (h)(2) is amended to include subsection (a)(1) or (a)(4). WAIVER OF SOVEREIGN IMMUNITY FOR ENFORCEMENT OF EMPLOYMENT AND REEMPLOYMENT RIGHTS OF MEMBERS OF UNIFORMED SERVICES. Paragraph (2) of section 4323(b) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to allow actions against a State, its instrumentalities, or officers/employees in their official capacity to be brought in federal or state courts without immunity under the Eleventh Amendment or sovereign immunity doctrines. Actions against a State, its instrumentalities, or officers/employees in their official capacity that receive Federal financial assistance can be brought in federal or state courts without immunity under the Eleventh Amendment or sovereign immunity doctrines. Courts may award remedies available under subsections (d) and (e) in such cases. The amendment to Section 4323(c)(2) of title 38, United States Code, expands the venue options for cases against private employers for violations of employment and reemployment rights of members of the uniformed services. The amendment allows such cases to be brought in the United States district court based on the employer's place of business, where the events giving rise to the claim occurred, or where the employer is subject to the court's jurisdiction. SEC. 5 amends Section 4323(f) of title 38, United States Code, regarding violations of employment and reemployment rights of uniformed services members by states and private employers. SEC. 6 addresses civil investigative demands by the Attorney General for enforcement of these rights. Section 4323 of title 38, United States Code is amended to allow the Attorney General to issue civil investigative demands for documentary material relevant to investigations before commencing a civil action. The Attorney General can issue civil investigative demands for documentary material relevant to investigations before starting a civil action. The provisions for issuing demands under the False Claims Act apply, with adjustments for this chapter. The Attorney General can issue civil investigative demands for relevant documentary material before starting a civil action. The False Claims Act provisions apply with adjustments for this chapter, including exemptions from certain definitions and provisions related to qui tam relators. Section 4313(a)(3) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include disabilities brought to the employer's attention within 5 years after resuming employment. Additionally, a new subsection is added stating that the employer is responsible for identifying appropriate reemployment positions for employees entitled to reemployment by reason of uniformed service status.
